Blog.post: and I'm getting a little worried that everything won't fit into my car. I really wanted to only have the trunk packed, and with light things, but it looks like there may be some overspill. On the other hand, I had Ethiopian food for the first time tonight, and it was very good. the restaurant was pretty nice on the inside, but the from the outside it looks like a place I wouldn't look at twice. I should be better about trying small hole-in-the-wall places, but I let other people try them first and then persuade me to go. Heheheh.
urlLink Then the light got softer and softer and the pictures became less spectacular. A lot of people think of California as bigcities, but most of it is really farmland.
urlLink This was a little farm we passed where I caught a glimpse of this pond and went "Ooo!"
urlLink The Clouds looked really weird. They were dark grey and higging the mountains in the distance.
urlLink I love this picture. We were on our way back from Monterey, and the sun was hitting the land on one side of the car. It was very beautiful and the air was clean and cool.
urlLink Mom looking gorgeous and smiling despite her frozen feet.
urlLink The kelp beds behind the aquarium.
urlLink Stupid smelly sea lions. They make a noise that sounds like they're saying, "Help me, Ma! I'm drowning! Gourp! Gourp! Gourp! Gourp! Gourp!"
urlLink Wind socks, wind socks...
urlLink And all the other people taking pictures, too.
urlLink A side view of the marina.
urlLink I think that this is also an otter. Was it stalking us?!
urlLink The kayakers out of their cove.
urlLink a fishing boat and a houseboat.
urlLink I think that's an otter.
urlLink The monkey and his man.
urlLink The wharf.
urlLink The second glimpse.
urlLink The eucalyptus corridor? (Who knows if I spelled it right?)
urlLink Taking pictures out of the car windo works pretty wel.
urlLink The sky was beautiful on the way down.

It's been a great weekend. Yesterday Mom and I took my car for a test spin down to Monterey. We stopped at Gilroy on the way and shopped but did not drop--and now I've got two places to wear earrings again. Monterey was beautiful, and we spent an hour shopping for jewelery. We also took lots of pictures, and ate waaaaaaaaaaay too much out on the pier. The car held up great. Pictures will follow.
There are a lot more pictures to put up, but it's taking too long with my dial-up connection.
urlLink But it's really pretty big.
urlLink The garden looks small here.

I'm new to all this blogging, despite hours spent reading other people's blogs. What a strange way to waste time...reading the thoughts of people you'll never meet. Unlimited photo hosting, eh? I'll have to test that, once I figure out how to add more than one photo to each entry.
urlLink Various roses
urlLink Mom in the Rose Garden
urlLink A rose is a rose is a rose... urlLink
It T-minus 12 days and I'm getting ready for move number 30. What wonderful inspirational things can I post here on the internet? Who knows?
So, it's been a long trip and a long time. I'm sorting through the photos and getting ready to post them. Patience, my non-read blog. Soon you will be full of fresh pictures...

Phew! Six days of driving and a broken computer later, I'm in NY! The last day (last Saturday) I drove form Joliet, IL to East Northport, NY. For those of the lazy persuasion, that's 847 miles, according to Mapquest. I'm online for the first time using a wireless router. The internet connection is downstairs, in a small room with a hard chair, while I'm upstairs lounging in an armchair, going "Mwaaaahaaaahaaaaaa, my bottom is sitting on a soft thing instead of a hard thing." My friends know I'm here and of course are busy people, so I'm trying to figure out how to relax. I'm not good at it. Look for pictures coming soon; I have to sort through most of them from the trip. My computer died on the second day, so I have a lot of pics from the first day of driving that are now on the hard drive, but all the rest of the week is still on the camera. It's strange; somehow being here in New York is making me think a lot about what it was like living in Hawai'i. Strange. I am looking forward soooo much to school starting!
urlLink Raphael coming in from a paddle.
urlLink What a great photo of a horse's butt.
urlLink She helped me move the day before. We both fell asleep on the beach, and I still have the strange tan lines.
urlLink Mom wondered what she would look like in sepia.

urlLink Setting out.
urlLink Goodbye, balcony.
urlLink I get the feeling he didn't want to leave.
urlLink It's rare to find someone who can beam like this and still teach me how to cange diapers regulation-style.
urlLink Alex(is) is now being dead. We developed this technique as a way to get out of rehearsal, but unfortunately he still tends to be ticklish.
urlLink The elusive 1998 The Alameda. Just like the purloined letter, it's hiding out in the open.
urlLink Trees at my old home.
urlLink The obligatory photo of myself (not the famine victim).

I just realised that I'm leaving the country in a little over a month, and I have no pants! Perhaps I should repharase that, as I'm heading to England, where they'll think I have no underwear. All I know is, for some reason when I was packing to drive to NY I thought that I would never need pants again and threw them all away. I'm hoping it's because they were all too big, and not because my brain was rotting away... I've been doing a lot of thinking the past few days. Yes, I know it looks like sleeping to all of you outside my head, but I assure you if I'm sleeping it's because I'm trying not to think. I talked to Leslie about this (Leslie, not Leslee) and it's just mindboggling to me how incredibly my friends are growing up. Yes, all both of them. They have retained all the essential them-ness and developed to be so interesting. Here I thought I've changed so much, and then I see them and I begin to worry that I haven't changed as much for the better as I had thought. That's enough philosophizing for now; I've got to count sweaters. More later, oh unread silly blog of the ages.

I drove down to Balmer, hon. I watched some very loud people scream for a while, then went outside to cool off. Then Kecak came on and my night became great. I love it when bands are better in person than they are in recordings, and Compliance and Liability is a damn good album. (www.geocities.com/wearekecak) There are a few more photos than these. Email me if you want to see more.
urlLink A subtle hint from Mike that it's time to be on my way.
urlLink No, I wasn't on herion for this shot.
urlLink Which are better: the cool but blurry photos, or the stark scary red-eye ones?
urlLink What these guys don't know is that while they're petting Mike's very sweaty head they're being hog-tied by Seb, heheheh.
urlLink A pre-show basement. Sweat, anyone?
urlLink Beth has apparently hit the "smarm" button concealed in makfak's left shoulder. I'm not sure how cocky he'll look when he realises what a heavy sleeper he is...

urlLink This is the last picture I took of the trip. It got too dark after this. I think this is still in Ohio. After this I finished Ohio, went across PA and NJ, then hit L.I. I hit the first bad weather of the trip going over the Poconos. It was pitch black and I couldn't really tell where I was going. By the time I got to NJ I was hitting myself to stay awake, but hey, it worked. It was a six day trip, 847 miles (according to Mapquest) the last day, from Joliet, IL to East Northport, NY.
urlLink An ominous sign. I had great weather for the whole trip until now.
urlLink Maybe this is the Mississippi. I don't think so. Who cares? It's a river, ooh.
urlLink NYC is on the radar.
urlLink So much to DISCOVER! *squeal*
urlLink Hmmm...this looks like Nebraska. Or is it Iowa? Ohio? Nope, it's Illinois.
urlLink Heading back into familiar territory, the outskirts of Illinois.
urlLink Welcome to Ohio.
urlLink At some point I crossed into Indiana, but there was no sign up because of construction.
urlLink The last day.
urlLink Welcome to Iowa.
urlLink Nowhere is kinda pretty.
urlLink A big something.
urlLink Welcome to Illinois. Please give us your money and then leave.
urlLink Where does all this "land" stuff come from?I saw it all across the country: Nebraskaland, Chicagoland, etc. People are weird.
urlLink Possibly the Mississippi, but I've waited so long to post these I don't remember anymore.
urlLink I WAS nowhere.
urlLink This is supposedly the biggest rest stop on 80. It was pretty big, but the lines were very long everywhere inside.
urlLink I have no clue what this thing is, but not bad for a view from a gas station.
urlLink Traffic?! You mean there are other people in Nebraska?!
urlLink Nowhere.
urlLink Welcome to Nebraska.
urlLink Ah, the lovely soft beaches of long island.
urlLink The dolphins, empty of ferries for the moment.
urlLink Even the air here is dripping wet.
urlLink Yup, it was a crowded beach.
urlLink Some sort of island. Gradiner's? Plum? Me not know.
urlLink The ferries coming in and out.
urlLink A light house at Orient point, LI
urlLink An interesting take on a house in the suburbs with a white picket fence.
urlLink Branson holds the shirt he is purchasing, while saying "Wisconsin." This picture says "Wisconsin," in his voice, but I haven't figured out how to make it play anywhere else yet.
urlLink Went for Korean dumpings with Leslie and Branson (here they are reminiscing about either RI or Balmer);
urlLink Helped Leslie pick out flatware at Macy's on 34 ave (it has cool wooden escalators);

urlLink Went shopping with them in Soho, where we discussed the job interview Branson had come to NY to have, and how Land's End wants him to move to Wisconsin. Here is Leslie looking perturbed about something, possible Wisconsin.
urlLink That's enough about the trip for tonight. Meanwhile, I've been in NY for a month, and what have I done?
urlLink Took surprise photos of Branson (or Billy, whichever makes him make a more awful face);
urlLink A very loooooong train.
urlLink I don't know what this is but it gave me something to wonder about for a while.
urlLink My huge motel room in Evanston. I couldn't believe how big it was.
urlLink Day three. Heading out of Evanston.

urlLink Moments before I open my backpack to discover my computer refuses to wake up. From here on there are fewer pictures of everything, as I had intended to empty my storage cards every night and couldn't.
urlLink Mom, these are the "scattered herds of cattle" I was talking about.
urlLink On my way to the motel. I kept having to remember that I was in Evanston WYOMING, not ILLINOIS. I was pretty tired.
urlLink I did like western Wyoming. It felt very big and free, unlike the mountains of SLC, which were pretty but really made it a lot of effort to leave SLC>
urlLink The road goes ever on and on...
urlLink I think it's time to wash the windows again.
urlLink Welcome to Wyoming, yee-haw.
urlLink It got lumpier.
urlLink Ah, meadowy.
urlLink And then it flattened out. This is the beinning of western Wyoming.
urlLink I think I would get claustrophoic living in one of these houses.
urlLink SLC
urlLink Hello...hello...hello...hello...

urlLink This was a really beutiful place to drive around. Salt Lake City (viewed in passing, at least) is so refreching to the eyes after the bleakness of the beginning of this journey. I really enjoyed it, especially as I didn't find out that my computer was broken until I stopped for my second night.
urlLink In interesting ways.
urlLink The state lines pretty much make sense. All the states I've been to are different, and you can tell when one state is ending and another beginning. Here is where Utah started to change.
urlLink More SLC. These mountinas were very pretty to look at but slowed me down a lot.
urlLink Yup. Lots of trains.
urlLink Approaching eastern Utah.
urlLink I passed a lot of trains on this trip.
urlLink Of course I had to see Cheyenne; I went shopping there later that day at Sierra trading post. A great store.
urlLink Around Salt Lake City. The most cars I'd seen on the road in hundreds of miles, really since Sacramento.
urlLink A weird shot tower or something...who knows?
urlLink Here is western Utah. It still looks like Nevada, but is a bit better.
urlLink Utah was much prettier than Nevada!
urlLink I think this is the great salt lake. There were no signs here but it was the only huge body of water and it was in about the right location.
urlLink It was something to think about, not just endless miles of desert.
urlLink Welcome to Utah
urlLink I saw these and hoped very fervently that the road somehow didn't go through these. It didn't, instead it curved around, but from here it looked like I'd have to get a snow shovel.
urlLink I should've painted black spots on my car before I set out.
urlLink For some reason, CA likes to label their mountains (like "South San Francisco, the Industrial City; and Hollywood) but NV doesn't seem to have quite grasped the idea.
urlLink Day two: There was a big sign up about 50 miles before this boasting that the Washington Post had voted Battle Mountain, NV is the armpit of the US. Naturally I had to take a picture.
urlLink This is interesting: heat shimmers on the road and snow on the mountains.
urlLink And here is what Winnemucca looks like.
urlLink I finally found gas and was tempted to turn around and go back...but I did wonder what some place called "Winnemucca" looked like.
urlLink Yee-haw, cowboy.
urlLink Yup. Did I mention it's boring?

urlLink Nevada is very boring. Very. And the signs lie. They told me it was 40 miles to the next gas station, so I kept going, but it was 97 miles and I was worried about how long I would have to wait to get off the side of the road. I'd probably still be there.
urlLink Donner pass. Descending from about 7,000-8,000 feet. I'll have to watch the little video I made for the exact number.
urlLink This bird apparently gets carsick.
urlLink I think the mountain ate some bad sushi.
urlLink It's weird to see snow in CA.
urlLink Yes, I liked the sky.
urlLink The first glimpse of snow. Remember, this was May 31.

urlLink Okay, while technically not a knitting picture--four skeins of handspun merino having its twist set. I still have oh, probably two pounds or more of this left to spin before I leave for school. I've debated about taking my wheel with me, but I'll probably have a lot of work to do...

Having just joined Secret Pal III I felt that although from this blog it looks like all I do is drive around and take pictures, I really do knit. A lot. In fact it's becoming an obsession, but fortunately I won't have a LOT of time to do it in about three weeks...hopefully. But since most of what I make seems to find its way to other people's houses anyway, I may as well find someone else to make happy with random acts of fiber thingies.
The damn school has sent my loan forms somewhere into oblivion. No wonder I haven't heard anything yet. I'm supposed to leave in 31 days. I have no loan and therefore no visa. Hence the 3 am posting.
